Is Da Vinciâ€™s masterpiece, the Mona Lisa, worth the hype?

By Emily Warner

Emily Warner (she/her) questions if the world-renowned â€˜Mona Lisaâ€™ is worthy of her popularity.

Stockholm

Let's get a couple of things clear. I loathe promenade performance

Fusion

Whatever your preconceptions of Fusion may be, tonight's show proved to be a passionate and dynamic display of some of York's biggest societies

Zeitoun

Tackling a subject as contentious as the US government's response to Hurricane Katrina is a brave and risky act by any novelist

The History Boys

Poetry, history and journalism - three of my favourite things. Combine them together in a huge theatrical melting pot and I am a happy girl

Anna Chocola

'Handmade', the current exhibition at the Norman Rea Gallery celebrates the use of 'traditional' skills in contemporary art, illustration and design, looking in particular at work with textiles (Thumbnail credit One Day by Anna Chocola exhibited at the Norman Rea)

Rope

As a piece of theatre, and as a true story, Rope does not lend itself to cheerful thinking. The play is based somewhat on the real case of Loeb and Leopold, two thrill-seeking wealthy students with a superiority complex gleaned from the pages of academia, who needlessly murder an innocent with the belief that they will remain undiscovered

The Fastest Clock in the Universe

The stage was set for the birthday party of the year with the (overcrowded) audience as its guests of honour

Adam Ross about his first novel

By James Bithell

Matt Fisketjon talks to Adam Ross about publishing his first novel (Thumbnail credit Adam Ross)

Award winning artist Pavel Buchler talks about his recent works with Beth Walton

Award-winning artist and research professor at the Manchester School of Art Pavel Buchler is a modest man; quite contrary to the portrait of a 'strict conceptual artist' he confesses he probably should be (Thumbnail credit Pavel Buchler, "Eclipse", copyright Pavel Buchler.)

Up and coming events

By James Bithell

Alan Johnston: Drawing a Shadow, Handmade, and Deutsch Borse Photography Prize

Lowenna Waters

Earlier this month Alberto Giacometti's L'Homme qui marche I (Walking Man I) sold for PS65 million at Sotherby's London, making it the most expensive artwork ever to be sold at auction

Motortown

Simon Stephen's Motortown is just the sort of 'In Yer Face' theatre that could remind people why seeing plays can be rewarding and provocative and yet as politically sharp as a Dispatches documentary

Cigarettes and Chocolate

I usually feel uncommonly claustrophobic and uncomfortable in York Theatre Royal's tiny Studio room

Rent

Thanks to Team America, many York students watching Rent this weekend will go into Central Hall thinking that they're going to see the musical where Everyone Has Aids

Art Exhibit: 100 Years of Gifts

100 Years of Gifts is a fascinating exploration of British art throughout the last century (Thumbnail credit Christopher Wood, The Harbour, 1926, Mercer Art Gallery, Harrogate Museums and Arts, Harrogate Borough Council)

Wit

"Nothing but a breath - a comma - separates life from life everlasting. It's very simple really: it's a comma, a pause."

David O'Doherty Comedy

When you don't live in London, it's always exciting when a critically acclaimed comedian comes to your town

Pantsoc Presents: Dick Whittington

I have been to the pantomime at least once every year of my life, being taught from day one that this is tradition

The Sun in The Cellar

On arrival I was anxious for a number of reasons; the first was due to the play being student written, not for fear of lack of quality but because I had no idea what to expect

As is painting, so is poetry

Unlike previous exhibition <em>Place Making</em>, the Norman Rea Gallery's new show, <em>As is Painting, so is poetry</em> boasts a youthful energy more suited to a University Art Gallery (Thumbnail credit Pequod/Princess Alice (2008) Ink on paper, copyright David Steans)

Mike Ballard about his new exhibition

When artist Mike Ballard was commissioned to exhibit at the Arts Gallery he was understandably daunted (Thumbnail credit Mike Ballard, the all of everything, copyright Mike Ballard)

Lowenna Valerie Waters

As we say goodbye to the noughties and welcome in a new decade, what are we to expect from a new era in British Art?

Hannah Barry Contemporary Art Gallery

Deep in the streets of South East London there is a cultural phenomenon occurring (Thumbnail credit VIKTORTIMOFEEV.LOCAL_AREA_NET-WORK[s]. January 2010 Hannah Barry Gallery, London)

Up and coming events

The Norma Rea Gallery open its doors for another term this week

M. Butterfly

Arriving to see <em>M. Butterfly</em>, I was glad I already had a ticket reserved: waiting at the doors was the largest audience I'd seen for a Drama Barn production in months

Jim Brogden and Mathew Shelton talk about Signs of Life

Beth Walton talks to artists Jim Brogden and Mathew Shelton about <em>Signs of Life</em>, one of the latest shows to open its doors at Project Space Leeds (Thumbnail credit Jim Brogden - Towards Bridgewater Place)

The Freshers' plays

The Freshers' plays, in allowing anyone new to acting or backstage work to take part in a production, are an important part of keeping drama at York fresh

Anish Kapoor at the Royal Academy: A conversation with Dr Adrian Locke

A wax canon, a pregnant wall, and several funfair mirrors are among the assortment of treats currently being shown at the Royal Academy of Art. But the exhibition is just a taster of the celebrated career of contemporary sculptor Anish Kapoor (Thumbnail credit Anish Kapoor - 'Greyman Cries, Shaman Dies, Billowing Smoke, Beauty Evoked', 2008-9 installed at the Royal Academy of Arts, London, Collection of the artist, Photo: John Bodkin)

Place Making

<em>Place Making</em>, on display at the Norman Rea Gallery, is a bold yet engaging exhibition of sculpture, prints and paintings by David Fitzpatrick (Thumbnail credit David Fitzpatrick - Pocket)

Erotic books come out of the closet

By James Bithell

Simon Finch is undoubtedly a maverick of the rare and antiquarian book world
